_meta.description: Comprehensive Illinois General Assembly bill action type reference. Derived from analysis of 103,332 actions across 11,722 bills (104th GA).

categories.label: Introduction & Filing
categories.description: Bill submitted and formally introduced into the legislative record.

actions.meaning: Bill submitted before the legislative session officially begins. No impact on outcome yet.
Bill officially submitted to the House Clerk during the session.
Bill officially submitted to the Senate Secretary during the session.
Formal introduction — title read into the official record. Required procedural step; bill now exists in the system.

actions.pattern: Read in Full a First Time
actions.meaning: Full text of the bill (usually a resolution) read aloud for the first time.

categories.label: Committee Assignment
categories.description: Bill sent to a substantive committee for review. Bills must be assigned before they can advance.

actions.meaning: Sent to a committee (usually Rules in the House, Assignments in the Senate). The gatekeeping step — Rules/Assignments decides which substantive committee hears the bill.
Sent to a substantive committee (e.g., Transportation, Revenue). This is where the bill gets a real hearing and evaluation.
Senate Assignments Committee forwards the bill to a substantive committee.
Bill moved from one substantive committee to another. Can indicate strategic maneuvering or jurisdictional correction.
Senate Assignments Committee approves the bill for committee consideration — a positive gate.
Referred to a subcommittee for more focused review (e.g., 'To Tax Policy: Other Taxes Subcommittee').
Subcommittee sends the bill back to the parent committee after review.

categories.label: Committee Action
categories.description: Committee votes or acts on the bill. This is the first major hurdle — most bills die in committee.

actions.meaning: Committee recommends passage and places it on the Short Debate calendar (limited floor discussion time). Strong positive signal — committee believes bill has broad support.
Committee recommends passage on the Standard Debate calendar (full floor discussion). Positive signal — bill expected to have substantive floor debate.
Committee recommends passage. The most important positive gate — majority of bills never get here.
Committee formally recommends the bill for passage.
Committee recommends passage via Consent Calendar — indicating the bill is non-controversial and expected to pass unanimously.
Bill passed via Consent Calendar (non-controversial, usually unanimous). Strong positive signal.
Committee recommends AGAINST passage. Rarely used in IL — bills are more commonly just never called for a vote.
Committee hearing postponed. Routine procedural action — does NOT mean the bill is dead. Sponsor may be gathering votes or negotiating amendments.
Committee waives the normal 6-day advance posting requirement. Often signals urgency or leadership priority.

categories.label: Deadlines & Re-referrals
categories.description: Deadline-related actions. In IL, bills that miss deadlines are re-referred to Rules/Assignments — not killed, but significantly slowed.

actions.meaning: MISSED COMMITTEE DEADLINE — bill did not get a committee vote before the deadline and is re-referred to Rules/Assignments. The bill is NOT dead but faces an uphill battle to be reassigned. Most bills that hit Rule 19(a) do not advance.
MISSED FLOOR DEADLINE — bill passed committee but did not get a floor vote (2nd/3rd Reading) before the deadline. Re-referred to Rules. Bill had momentum but stalled.
Amendment missed its deadline. Only applies to amendments, not the bill itself.
Senate committee deadline set or extended. Procedural — establishes when the bill must be voted out of committee.
Senate Third Reading (floor vote) deadline set or extended.
Combined committee and floor deadline set for Senate bill.
Floor vote deadline extended. Mildly positive — leadership granted more time, suggesting the bill has support but needs more negotiation.
Committee or final action deadline extended.
Floor vote and final action deadline extended.
Senate procedural rule — bill re-referred to Assignments for missing Rule 2-10 deadline. Bill is NOT dead but faces uphill battle.
Senate procedural re-referral to Assignments — 31 consecutive days without session.

categories.label: Floor Process
categories.description: Actions related to floor debate and voting stages (Second Reading, Third Reading).

actions.meaning: Bill reaches the floor amendment stage on Short Debate calendar. Major milestone — bill has passed committee and is on the floor.
Bill reaches the floor amendment stage. Floor amendments can be offered here.

actions.pattern: Held on Calendar Order of Second Reading
actions.meaning: Bill was ready for Second Reading but was paused/held by the sponsor. Usually indicates the sponsor is still negotiating amendments or gathering votes. NOT a negative signal — the sponsor controls the pace.
Bill placed on the Second Reading calendar. Positive — bill is queued for floor action.

actions.pattern: Placed on Calendar Order of 2nd Reading
actions.meaning: Bill placed on the order of Second Reading.
Bill reaches final debate and vote stage. This is the last step before the floor vote.

actions.pattern: Placed on Calendar Order of 3rd Reading
actions.meaning: Bill placed on the Third Reading calendar — queued for final vote.
Bill pulled back from Third Reading to Second Reading, usually to adopt a floor amendment. Common and not negative — sponsors often recall bills to incorporate negotiated changes.

actions.pattern: Chair Rules placed on Standard debate
actions.meaning: Rules Committee chair moves bill from Short Debate to Standard Debate, indicating it needs more floor discussion time.
Bill requires a supermajority (3/5) to pass. Higher bar — typically for appropriations, preemption, or immediate effective dates.

categories.label: Floor Vote
categories.description: Chamber votes on the bill. Passing here means the bill has cleared one chamber.

actions.meaning: Bill PASSED a floor vote on Third Reading. Major milestone — bill has cleared one chamber.
Bill PASSED on Short Debate Third Reading. Bill cleared the chamber.
Bill FAILED a floor vote. Rare — sponsors usually don't call a vote unless they have the votes. Very negative signal.
Bill FAILED a floor vote on Short Debate. Negative — bill rejected by the chamber.
Resolution passed by the chamber.
Bill or resolution adopted by the chamber.

categories.label: Cross-Chamber
categories.description: Bill moves between chambers (House <-> Senate). Indicates the bill passed its origin chamber.

actions.meaning: House bill arrives in the Senate after passing the House.
Senate bill arrives in the House after passing the Senate.
Bill crosses to the other chamber after passing its origin chamber.
Second chamber formally receives the bill and assigns a chamber sponsor.
House sponsor assigned for a Senate bill — bill is being actively managed in the second chamber.
Senate sponsor assigned for a House bill.
Alternate chief sponsor designated.
Chief sponsor changed — may indicate leadership taking ownership or a strategic handoff.

categories.label: Concurrence
categories.description: When one chamber amends a bill from the other chamber, the origin chamber must concur (agree) with the changes.
categories.rule_reference: Senate Rule 8-1/Article VIII; House Rule 72/Article VIII

actions.meaning: Bill PASSED BOTH CHAMBERS. Major milestone — bill goes to the Governor next.
Resolution adopted by both chambers.
House agrees with Senate amendments to the bill.
Senate agrees with House amendments to the bill.
Bill placed on Secretary's Desk awaiting Senate concurrence vote on House amendments.

actions.pattern: Placed on Calendar Order of Concurrence
actions.meaning: Concurrence vote scheduled on the calendar.
Motion filed to agree with the other chamber's amendments.

categories.label: Governor Action
categories.description: Governor signs, vetoes, or takes other action on the bill.
categories.rule_reference: Senate Article IX/Rules 9-1 to 9-6; House Article IX/Rules 77-82

actions.meaning: Bill transmitted to the Governor for signature. Strong positive — bill has passed both chambers.
GOVERNOR SIGNED THE BILL. Bill is now law (pending effective date).
Governor certifies changes made under an amendatory veto.
GOVERNOR VETOED THE BILL. Bill is dead unless the legislature overrides (requires 3/5 vote in both chambers).
Governor returns the bill with specific recommended changes. Legislature can accept the changes, override, or let the bill die.
Governor vetoes or reduces specific line items in an appropriations bill. Only applies to budget bills.

categories.label: Veto Override Process
categories.description: Legislative response to a governor's veto.
categories.rule_reference: Senate Article IX/Rules 9-3 to 9-6; House Article IX/Rules 79-82

actions.meaning: Legislature schedules consideration of overriding a total veto.
Legislature schedules consideration of overriding a total veto.
Legislature schedules consideration of an amendatory veto — will vote to accept changes or override.
Legislature schedules consideration of a reduction/item veto.
Legislature FAILED to override the veto, or took no action. BILL IS DEAD.
Legislature did not override the item/reduction veto. Those provisions are dead.
Motion filed regarding an amendatory veto (accept changes, override, etc.).
Motion filed to override the governor's veto.
Bill signed into law — assigned a Public Act number (e.g., PA 104-0032).
Law's effective date announced. Most IL laws take effect January 1 of the next year unless otherwise specified.
Executive appointment confirmed by the Senate. The appointment equivalent of a bill becoming law.

categories.label: Co-Sponsorship
categories.description: Members adding or removing their co-sponsorship of the bill. More co-sponsors generally signals broader support.

actions.meaning: A legislator adds their name as co-sponsor, signaling public support for the bill.
A legislator added as co-sponsor.
Alternate co-sponsor added.
Alternate chief co-sponsor added.
Alternate co-sponsor added in the second chamber.
Alternate chief co-sponsor added.
A legislator takes on the chief co-sponsor role, a stronger commitment than regular co-sponsorship.
Chief co-sponsor added.
Entire chamber added as co-sponsors — typically for ceremonial or consensus resolutions.
Co-sponsor removed their support. Mildly negative — someone withdrew.
Co-sponsor removed.

categories.label: Amendment Actions
categories.description: Actions on amendments to the bill. Amendments modify bill text and go through their own mini-process (filed, referred, adopted/tabled).

actions.meaning: Action on a House committee amendment — amendment is being processed.
Action on a House floor amendment — amendment is being processed during Second Reading.
Action on a Senate committee amendment.
Action on a Senate floor amendment.
Conference committee report action — chambers negotiating differences.

categories.label: Resolution Process
categories.description: Actions specific to resolutions (HR, SR, HJR, SJR). Resolutions follow a simplified process.

actions.meaning: Resolution placed on consent calendar — expected to pass without debate.
Congratulatory resolution placed on consent calendar — ceremonial, will pass easily.
Resolution placed on agreed resolutions calendar — non-controversial batch passage.

actions.pattern: Placed on Calendar Order of Resolutions
actions.meaning: Resolution queued for consideration.

actions.pattern: Placed on Calendar Order of Secretary's Desk Resolutions
actions.meaning: Resolution placed on Secretary's Desk for Senate consideration.

categories.label: Executive Appointments
categories.description: Actions related to gubernatorial appointments that require Senate confirmation.

actions.meaning: Appointment carried over from previous General Assembly — not yet acted on.
Appointment message superseded by a newer appointment message.
Multiple appointment messages compiled for a batch vote.
Motion filed to act on appointment messages.

categories.label: Procedural
categories.description: Procedural motions and administrative actions that don't directly advance or block the bill.

actions.meaning: A procedural motion passed.
Motion to suspend a rule (e.g., Rule 21 posting requirement). Often signals urgency.
Rule suspension motion passed. The rule is temporarily set aside for this bill.
Motion to reconsider a previous vote. Can be used to revive a failed vote or to lock in a successful one.

actions.pattern: Placed on Calendar Order of First Reading
actions.meaning: Bill queued for First Reading in the second chamber.
Bill or appointment withdrawn per rule. For appointments, usually means the appointment was superseded.

Bill tabled — temporarily set aside. In IL, tabling is less final than in Congress; bills can be brought back (Rule 7-11). But it's a negative signal when the bill itself (not an amendment) is tabled.
Reference to the previous General Assembly's adjournment sine die. Appointments from the prior GA are noted as carried over.

outcome_signal_definitions.positive_terminal: Bill has become law or confirmed. Final positive outcome.
outcome_signal_definitions.positive: Bill is making meaningful forward progress.
outcome_signal_definitions.positive_weak: Mildly positive — incremental signal, not decisive.
outcome_signal_definitions.neutral: Procedural or administrative — no bearing on outcome.
outcome_signal_definitions.negative_weak: Mildly negative — bill faces obstacles but is not dead.
outcome_signal_definitions.negative: Significant setback — bill failed a vote or was rejected.
outcome_signal_definitions.negative_terminal: Bill is dead — governor vetoed and override failed.
